title: Hekonai #2
body:
I burst into the swordmaker's shop! Well, stumbled is more honest: my heroic reflexes are a work in progress.

I was ready to challenge the swordmaker... but no one was there. On the table was the most magnificent sword I've ever seen, with a note next to it. It read "Fall seven times, stand up eight."Â  I thought to myself: *is this fate showing its hand?*Â  I took the sword from its sheath and its blade burst into flame!

![Illustration by Mirsub Fazlani (innovativepixels_art)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/HElKwGMqVlre7ejYJFK8Z.jpg?height=458&width=1413)

At that moment, a magic feeling rippled through my entire being. I looked down and saw my body reshape and transform itself. I looked over at a mirror: my face became the artfully drawn one I saw on the moon's surface. I felt like a butterfly emerging from its chrysalis. It was glorious.

I let out my best heroic yell and swung the sword. It opened a slash in space and time! Through it, I saw a dark void. It looked like an impossibly long hallway with swirling lights at the end.Â  I froze in my tracks. Everything was happening so fast.

![Illustration by Mirsub Fazlani (innovativepixels_art)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/8U0FL5NcKevsP1tC3j5Fy.png?height=565&width=1379&&&&size=medium)

Then I took a deep breath, put on my best 'fierce samurai' expression, and stepped into the void.

![Illustration by Mirsub Fazlani (innovativepixels_art)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/ppysTphr4t2IU6OevReqv.png?height=663&width=1192&&&&&size=large)

Please enjoy the next post #3 below in the Hekonai Journal:

[https://mirror.xyz/cryptoanimedao.eth/QLPwaWxefYTau2lqjwCeFhhghe0zWxt4FnLWfhumK4w](https://mirror.xyz/cryptoanimedao.eth/QLPwaWxefYTau2lqjwCeFhhghe0zWxt4FnLWfhumK4w)

**[Post Soundtrack:](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TJVxwPoHRSM)**[ Vessels - Philip Glass](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TJVxwPoHRSM)

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TJVxwPoHRSM](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TJVxwPoHRSM)

Into the authorâ€™s mind: *â€œThis awe-inspiring cue is part of the soundtrack for the documentary Koyaanisqatsi. When I first heard it, I was struck by how Glass could take minimalist melodic motifs and build them into this grandiose cathedral of sound through inventive arranging and layering of the elements. This post captures Hekonai's moment of rebirth so the sense of wonder and the sheer joy of creation in the music made it my immediate and obvious soundtrack choice.â€*

If you want to learn how it came to be, check out the introduction post by clicking [here](https://mirror.xyz/cryptoanimedao.eth/Kqx2WGy6yeTxUNEFloZyBJNMzG-HY-qjSn5sF5TQHvo). If you want to read the journal entries from the very beginning, click [here](https://mirror.xyz/cryptoanimedao.eth/5iAMrCM5CEnvK9v5kI_Q-XPrdDeI2ZFb81vITelNcIU).**

title: The anatomy of a cryptocurrency scam
body:
The story starts from a reddit bot post that went to an interesting image link. I couldnâ€™t help myself, I needed to see what this was all about. `https://imgtsj5.pics/tweet-saved-728347-16-06-22.png` ![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/2yAnvxYCCzBnllyDIqBQv.webp?height=371&width=438) The tweet is a decent looking fake, now I had the domain where the shenanigans were happening. Time to flex and bust out nslookup for the IP address and search for more data with Shodan. ``` borntobekyle@InTheShell:~/Documents/crypto_scam_research$ nslookup imgtsj5.pics Server: 127.0.0.53 Address: 127.0.0.53#53 Non-authoritative answer: Name: imgtsj5.pics Address: 198.54.114.189 ``` Running nslookup for the server's IP address and using Shodan revealed some interesting information for the domain `imgtsj5.pics`. The image server was running on Namecheap and seemed to only be used to serve fake tweets. --- ## Researching the scam site elonsdrop.org Using almost the same pattern `nslookup` â†’ `shodan` â†’ `researching Ethereum public addresses with etherscan.io` I was able to get all information needed to take down these servers. ``` borntobekyle@InTheShell:~/Documents/crypto_scam_research$ nslookup elonsdrop.org Server: 127.0.0.53 Address: 127.0.0.53#53 Non-authoritative answer: Name: elonsdrop.org Address: 198.54.116.86 ``` This websites index looked almost exactly like Medium. ![Literally borrowing Medium's CDN](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/8vkJ8fwne7OJd84zLYSzp.png?height=929&width=1579) ### Techniques used to make the site look authentic One of the reasons the scam site looks just like Medium is because the scammers used assets from Medium's CDN. **Using static assets of the official Medium site** ``` title: How does a monkey dominate the NFT industry? - Dar Ding - Medium
body:
![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*oG8OpE23QMmGQ-iZ1goVbg.jpeg)

NFT or known as Non-Fungible Token, can represent any digital asset on blockchain. Unlike real-life tokens, every one of these non-fungible tokens is unique and impossible to lose. NFT can be anything. Creators can tokenize their in-game items, digital artwork, music, avatars and event tickets into NFT and them online. Avatars are the massive hype for the NFT game.

Bored Apes are the most successful and priceless collection of NFTs by volume. The most expensive NFT in this series sold for a whopping $3.59 million. Global influencers like Stephen Curry, Shaq Oâ€™Neal and Justin Bieber all hold at least one of these apes as their social media profile. This insane NFT project has gone from the world of cryptocurrency into the real world of pop culture and fashion. If you donâ€™t know how Bored Ape made its own fortune, I will give you a little bit of insight into the Bored Apeâ€™s origin story.

## **What is Bored Ape?**

The Bored Ape Yacht Club (BAYC) is a collection of 10,000 NFT ape avatars. The apes in each image are generated by a unique algorithm. This algorithm can generate a total of 172 attributes of varying rarity. And then randomly disrupting the various combinations of background colour, fur colour, incarnation costume, hat, eyes, mouth shape and character accessories for each ape incarnation. Making each ape unique in the world. Unlike the Mona Lisa in Louvre, where a real-life forgery has to be identified by an expert, the NFT can be identified simply by its publicly available serial number.

The rarity will determine whether your ape is priceless or a cheapo. If the ape has less common combinations and accessories, it can lead to higher rarity. And the higher the rarity means the higher the offer. According to OpenSea, the world's first and largest NFT marketplace, one of the rarest NFTs in the series, Bored Ape #7495 (worth approximately $150,000), carries a dagger in its mouth, a trait possessed by only 48 other apes out of the 10,000 apes. (This algorithmically randomly generated attribute has a rare rarity of 0.49%)

These Boring Apes NFTs are bought, sold and traded using Ether (a type of cryptocurrency). They can be purchased on OpenSea. All information about each transaction can be presented on the platform. Take Bored Ape #7495 for example. Any user can check the Opensea website to find out the time of each transaction, the information about the counterparty, and even the amount of each transaction of this NFT item. Because they are publicly documented on the blockchain.

![This truncation record shows Bored Ape #7495 was minted on May 1st, 2021](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*xYnPlthtG4uNYvw6uPG5Fw.jpeg)

How did the average price of BAYC take a big leap jump from 0.08 ETH to 105 ETH? There are certainly a lot of special characters around BAYC, but apart from that, they have attracted millions of potential buyers and sellers through three marketing tricks.

## **Community Operations & Marketing**

BAYC is more than just a fun Jpeg to use for your Twitter profile, their ultimate goal is to be a global premium club. Your bored ape is the VIP pass for entry. Thatâ€™s why much of its commercial marketing revolves around its online community. When NFT was officially launched, the team began promoting the project on Twitter, and Discord, building up strong online communities that would allow BAYC holders to interact while sharing information. Even if you donâ€™t own any NFT, you can still join the BAYC discord community and participate in discussions on some of the channels to get the latest insight on NFT. This allows users from inside and outside the crypto community to be connected.

![A chat channel in the official BAYC discord community Non-NFT holders can also participate in the discussion](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*aT3J_matB7-m6-5p3OfjUw.png)

## **Member benefits**

BAYC owners can enjoy exclusive membership benefits in the club. Every owner will not only be able to participate in some exclusive offline parties, but BAYC will also grant consumers free NFTs for other product lines. In June 2021, every BAYC holder will receive a free virtual land NFT, Otherside. While these virtual lands are free for BAYC holders, if you are not a BAYC member you will need to pay 2.3 ETH (about $4,160) for the cheapest piece of Otherside virtual land. This step also paves the way for BAYC to build their Ape metaverse.

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*6RotTMXALw_V0CAb-IM7TQ.jpeg)

## **Brand Remake & Co-branding**

Each BAYC owner is given the right to use it commercially and they can build products on it. Unlike traditional artwork, the products are different. Once a consumer has purchased a Bored Ape NFT, the consumer can make and sell all kinds of peripherals with their Bored Ape IP on them: T-shirts, mugs, etc. With the help of BAYC, the customer becomes the owner. Li Ning bought BAYC #4102 in April this year, and at the end of the transaction, Li Ning not only received an NFT, but also commercial ownership of the Bored Ape IP #4102, which was added to the brandâ€™s new products for sale. BAYC is not only incentivizing individual users and commercial brands to create their own new commercial IPs through secondary IP ownership but is also giving its NFT a free wave of high-quality PR.

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*rcoRXIeUTQzFxlXlhRdEWg.jpeg)

## **Conclusion:**

Bored Ape is more than just an NFT collectorâ€™s item, it represents a status symbol in Web3. Its success is definitely not based on luck and hype alone. It is still very different from CryptoKitties, the NFT that was an instant success but whose bubble soon burst. The company is now launching its fourth series, Otherside Virtual Worlds, and is gradually expanding and refining its ecosystem. According to the roadmap released by BAYC, they want to create an NFT that is accessible in all areas, and I believe it will continue to improve its ape universe and create more value in the future.

![Board Ape Yacht Club NFT Releases Updated Roadmap](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*xGRvn6iS5K-ddK3aof0Evw.png)

body:
## Helping you â€˜Chip Inâ€™ to Bigger and Better Gifts

*In this article I explore Chipin and their â€˜Cheeky Chooksâ€™ collection, a project built around improving the gifting experience. If youâ€™ve ever found it awkward to pick the perfect present, this could be a solution for youâ€¦*


---

If youâ€™ve been following *[my writing](https://medium.com/@NotRealAqua/haunting-the-hungry-ghosts-80598c1f5bd8)* or *[twitter](https://twitter.com/aquathickshell)*, you probably know I spend a lot of time in Twitter Spaces learning more about various new NFT projects. Especially, I tend to listen to those run by the Aussie Alpha Collective (a group of Aussie web 3.0 projects collaborating to help grow the space, including the *[MetaBogans](https://mirror.xyz/0x6ca15C7F22e506210C013c639d505EC444989572/vCHv3edPrlfNnlYLoKG5g-DhuPQKx4EfaF1EIC_sryg)*, who Iâ€™ve covered before). One of the projects from the collective who Iâ€™ve heard consistently engage with the space are the â€˜**Cheeky Chooks**â€™ by ***Chipin***.

## Chipin

Before I get to the NFT side of things, itâ€™s worthwhile covering Chipin themselves for a bit of context.

![Chipin Logo via LinkedIn](https://miro.medium.com/max/400/0\*3G5w02p5Xhi1bvnF)

So who or what is Chipin? Chipin are an Aussie start-up built around improving the gifting experience. Coming from Melbourne, Chipin aims to minimise the wastage associated with unwanted gifting and improve the experience for everyone by giving people a simple platform to share their wishlist and contribute (or â€˜chip inâ€™) towards gifts for others.

How does it work? Simple: download the app, set up your profile, create a â€˜chiplistâ€™ and then share it around. If youâ€™re wanting to chip in to someone elseâ€™s gift, itâ€™s as simple as selecting the item, adding a message and sending the money.

## Cheeky Chooks

So now that we know what Chipinâ€™s all about, how do NFTs enter the picture?

![Cheeky Chooks Logo via @CheekyChooksNFT](https://miro.medium.com/max/800/0\*EXOJnf1_JPd7vsWN.jpg)

The Cheeky Chooks are an NFT collection consisting of 9,999 3D chooks. By holding a chook you entitle yourself to some of the profit share from the Chipin platform, gift raffles, a Chipin pro subscription, and even discounts related to your chooks attributes. Be sure to go ahead and check out their site for the full details.

If youâ€™ve ever found it difficult to choose the right gift, would love to help cut down on wastage from unwanted gifts or even just want to jump on the discounts and profit sharing, this may be a project you want to follow. Go ahead and check out the ***[Chipin website](https://www.chipin.blog/)***.


---

*If you like what you read, go ahead and follow me here, or check out my **[Twitter](https://twitter.com/aquathickshell)** and **[DeSo](https://bitclout.com/u/RealAqua)** profiles to stay up to date with what projects I explore.*

title: Content addressing and CIDs
body:
A *content identifier*, or CID, is a label used to point to material in IPFS. It doesn't indicate *where* the content is stored, but it forms a kind of address based on the content itself. CIDs are short, regardless of the size of their underlying content.

CIDs are based on the contentâ€™s [cryptographic hash](https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/hashing/). That means:

* Any difference in the content will produce a different CID and
* The same content added to two different IPFS nodes using the same settings will produce *the same CID*.

IPFS uses the `sha-256` hashing algorithm by default, but there is support for many other algorithms. The [Multihash (opens new window)](https://multiformats.io/multihash/)project represents the work for this, with the aim of future-proofing applications' use of hashes and allowing multiple hash functions to coexist. (If you're curious about how hash types in IPFS are decided upon, you may wish to keep an eye on [this forum discussion (opens new window)](https://discuss.ipfs.io/t/who-decides-what-hashing-algorithms-ipfs-allows/6742).)

## #Identifier formats

CIDs can take a few different forms with different encoding bases or CID versions. Many of the existing IPFS tools still generate v0 CIDs, although the `files` ([Mutable File System](https://docs.ipfs.io/concepts/file-systems/#mutable-file-system-mfs)) and `object` operations now use CIDv1 by default.

### #Version 0 (v0)

When IPFS was first designed, we used base 58-encoded multihashes as the content identifiers. This is simpler but much less flexible than newer CIDs. CIDv0 is still used by default for many IPFS operations, so you should generally support v0.

If a CID is 46 characters starting with "Qm", it's a CIDv0 (for more details, check the [decoding algorithm (opens new window)](https://github.com/ipld/cid/blob/ef1b2002394b15b1e6c26c30545fd485f2c4c138/README.md#decoding-algorithm)in the CID specification).

### #Version 1 (v1)

CID v1 contains some leading identifiers that clarify exactly which representation is used, along with the content-hash itself. These include:

* A [multibase (opens new window)](https://github.com/multiformats/multibase)prefix, specifying the encoding used for the remainder of the CID
* A CID version identifier, which indicates which version of CID this is
* A [multicodec (opens new window)](https://github.com/multiformats/multicodec)identifier, indicating the format of the target content â€” it helps people and software to know how to interpret that content after the content is fetched

These leading identifiers also provide forward-compatibility, supporting different formats to be used in future versions of CID.

You can use the first few bytes of the CID to interpret the remainder of the content address and know how to decode the content after being fetched from IPFS. For more details, check out the [CID specification (opens new window)](https://github.com/ipld/cid). It includes a [decoding algorithm (opens new window)](https://github.com/ipld/cid/blob/ef1b2002394b15b1e6c26c30545fd485f2c4c138/README.md#decoding-algorithm)and links to existing software implementations for decoding CIDs.

If you can't decide between CIDv0 and CIDv1, consider choosing CIDv1 for your new project and opt in by passing a version flag (`ipfs add --cid-version 1`). This is more future-proof and [safe for use in browser contexts](https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/address-ipfs-on-web/#subdomain-gateway).

The IPFS project will switch to CIDv1 as the new default in the near future.

## #CID Inspector

It's easy to explore a CID for yourself. Want to pull apart a specific CID's multibase, multicodec, or multihash info? You can use the [CID Inspector (opens new window)](https://cid.ipfs.io/#QmY7Yh4UquoXHLPFo2XbhXkhBvFoPwmQUSa92pxnxjQuPU)or the [CID Info panel in IPLD Explorer (opens new window)](https://explore.ipld.io/#/explore/QmY7Yh4UquoXHLPFo2XbhXkhBvFoPwmQUSa92pxnxjQuPU)(both links launch using a sample CID) for an interactive breakdown of differently-formatted CIDs.

Check out ProtoSchool's [Anatomy of a CID (opens new window)](https://proto.school/anatomy-of-a-cid)tutorial to see how a single file can be represented in multiple CID versions.

## #CID conversion

Converting a CID from v0 to v1 enables it to be represented in multibase encodings. 
 The default for CIDv1 is the case-insensitive `base32`, but use of the shorter `base36` is encouraged for IPNS names to ensure same text representation on [subdomains](https://docs.ipfs.io/how-to/address-ipfs-on-web/#subdomain-gateway).

title: Musings on web3
body:
**Since the dawn of humanity - our ability to create and share stories and narratives was key to enabling humans to effectively collaborate in large numbers, create complex organisations and institutions & reach breath-taking accomplishments-** think air & space travel, the declaration of human rights, vaccine developments, the internet - all these and more were achieved thanks to countless humans from different countries and languages collaborating through an intricate system of relationships enabled by abstract (made-up) concepts like companies, money, ownership rights- all that and more from Yuval Harrri's Homosapiens.

One of the most foundational aspects of these abstract concepts is that they all require the existence of a shared-belief or **consensus**. Consensus is an agreement amongst participants regarding the state or value of something and is a required condition for these institutions and concepts to emerge and sustain (think what would happen to your money if everyone around you would believe itâ€™s worthless). And here lies the challenges, shared values & beliefs are so foundational to the ongoing operation of our world. According to OECD: â€œTrust is the foundation for the legitimacy of public institutions and a functioning democratic systemâ€. But trust in these institutions has been slowly eroding over the past few yearsâ€¦

As humanity enters a period of growing turmoil and as further erosion in â€˜trust in institutionsâ€™ is expected, I find one area particularly interesting: Crypto & Blockchain technology..

\*\* 

Why?

Well, for me- itâ€™s all about how mathematics (Cryptography) is used to enable parties who donâ€™t know (or trust) one another, reach **consensus** over a trustless medium (like the internet) without central â€˜authorityâ€™ (or institution). This is massive. Blockchain technology, enables two people who donâ€™t know or trust one another to reach consensus (or shared agreed state) and therefore to transact with one another without any central government, bank, organisation in the middle that facilitates it. This foundational shift could very likely become another 'building blockâ€™ that would shape the future of humanity (as long as we trust in math :).

How?

Since Blockchains allow us to reach **consensus** we now have the ability to â€˜codifyâ€™ ownership (this could be money, land, property or even IP & digital-content) and align incentive systems in a way that doesnâ€™t require centralised â€˜consensus makersâ€™ like governments, banks, central-agencies, companies and other such institutions. For the first time, individuals can be truly self-sovereign owners of assets and property and can unequivocally prove that they are.

Codifying ownership may sound like not such a big deal to you- but perhaps thatâ€™s because you're living in a relatively lucky and well run country. But that could change. Ask your neighbours in Venezuela, Nigeria, Sudan, Iran, Lebanon or even Argentina and Turkey. (I have recently added Sri Lanka & Ukraine to the list which I believe going to get much longer as this decade progresses).

A new decentralised way to govern and aligning incentives can create new ways to govern and form massive collaborations across countries and geographies that could reshape the future (think new forms of governance and structures like DAOs)

Will the â€˜turmoil-twenties decadeâ€™ ahead of us accelerate the move towards self-sovereignty powered by blockchains? I think it mightâ€¦ I see a world in which true self-sovereign property rights are added as a basic Human-right in the year 2050.

\*\*
\*\*

What do you think?
